For anyone wondering how to POST with GraphQL using iOS Shortcuts, here's a screenshot of how to set it up.

You also want to format your query correctly.
- Escape any double-quotes.
- Any line breaks can be replaced with `\\n`.
- Wrap it inside `{ "query": "<formattedQuery>" }`. https://t.co/HIWWXO6D66
A little GQL query filtering, which then populates the mutation with specific updated parameters. Looped over that and POSTed to the Hasura endpoint U+2764

Just update 100+ DB rows in under 30s thanks to Shortcuts and GraphQL.

Watching the Shortcut go was beautiful U+1f642

@mattcassinelli The API has the ability to trigger webhooks with new data entries. I'd also like to make this data easily searchable on my website. But that's gonna be even more challenging. For now, I can pull the data, select a category, and open the URL via another Shortcut.
[10/10]

@mattcassinelli And that's it! Next, I want to finish up the static backup. I want to automate it via GitHub Actions so every time there's an update to the DB, it triggers the Action to pull from the API, save the updates to their respective files via Node, and then commit the changes.
[9/10]

@mattcassinelli That action parses the API response to determine if the content was saved successfully or not. If good, I get a notification letting me know. Otherwise, the response is parsed and I get an alert letting me know why it failed. The API has pretty helpful error messages.
[8/10]

@mattcassinelli There's a lot of other regexes that cleans up the Title and Creator fields. That's it's own Shortcut that can be reused elsewhere. The POST to my API is another action that's reused elsewhere. 
[7/10]

@mattcassinelli From there, it's just a matter of orchestrating and adding some conditional logic to it all for this to work automatically. The Shortcut determines what parameters to use based on the URL; where the content is coming from.
[6/10]

@mattcassinelli I have a repo that has a static copy of all my bookmarks in JSON. And I also have another JSON file with dictionaries corresponding to the regex need to parse each field for each corresponding category. Shortcuts reads the file via the Working Copy action.
[5/10]

@mattcassinelli The Shortcut pulls the webpage source and parses that for the various fields. All my Podcasts come from an Overcast URL. Reddits and Tweets come from their respective sites. And Videos are either YouTube or Vimeo. So what HTML I need to parse is quite predictable.
[4/10]

@mattcassinelli Each bookmark has 4 fields:
- Title
- Creator
- URL
- Category

Categories are:
- Articles
- Comics
- Podcasts
- Reddits
- Tweets
- Videos
[3/10]

@mattcassinelli So, after giving up on every bookmarking service, I decided to make my own. There were several iterations of this but ultimately landed on a  PostgreSQL database with a GraphQL API on top. That way I can use the **Get Contents of URL** action to POST my bookmarks.
[2/10]

@mattcassinelli TL;DR
Shortcut pulls source
U+2b07
Parses the data and extracts Title, Creator, URL, and I select a Category
U+2b07
Data is sent via **Get Contents of URL**
U+2b07
GraphQL API
U+2b07
PostgreSQL Database

[1/10]

For context, the Shortcut saves Articles, Webcomics, Podcasts, YouTubes, Tweets, and Reddits to a DB via an API.

In order to parse and extract the correct data, date separate Shortcuts and usually had to go into Safari for them to work.

Now it can be done from anywhere.

I just consolidate 3 Shortcuts with 40+ actions on each into a single 34 actions Shortcut. I'm so excited and proud and I don't know who to share this with that will appreciate it. So hey @mattcassinelli U+1f604
@ChristianSelig Definitely B!

@gatsbyjs - With a little word of mouth, I was soon making websites and getting paid.
- Three years later, I work full-time as a freelance web developer with the JAMstack. 2/2

@gatsbyjs - Left hardware repair job.
- While figuring out what to do next, I wanted to make an inexpensive blog.
- Stumbled upon Hugo and dove right into it.
- After learning how to build static sites, a friend asked me to build a website for his business. 1/2
All in all, solid upgrade. The employee discount hook-up was well worth it. And now, I have two different AirPods for no reason. Living the life.

Listening to podcasts sounds about the same. @romanmars sounds as sexy as ever. However, by the far the best feature is the new controls. Seriously. No longer will I have to punch my ears two or more times to pause. Now I just gentle squeeze the tip U+1f4a6

And that’s without the noise cancelling on! With it on, it feels like my ears are clogged. I tried wearing them with nothing on, just the noise cancelling. It felt terrible. But Apple quality terrible U+1f4af

The ambiance at home is quite. It’s just me 90% of the time, so my PC is the loudest thing in here. Also, I live in the suburbs so nothing ever happens here.

With the new AirPods, the silence at home is even more quite now. I’d say a good 30% improvement.

Here’s my comprehensive review of the AirPods Pro.

A bit of context:

I work from home and spend most of my time listening to podcast while I work.

But then again, I could also write a Shortcut that parses the CSV data and POSTs the new entries to my DB. It's just a couple of steps required on my end. But seem less automate, though. But I still have to migrate the existing Timelogger. Which means making the Shortcuts anyway.

I'd thought about switching to Toggle via the wonderful @timeryapp. But I'm not so sure how I feel about managing a Toggle account. However, that would mean I could easily connect the account to a @zapier trigger, for example, and schedule daily backups to a number of places.

Up until now, I've been running simultaneous timers. @timelogger_app allows for that. However, the data is trapped inside the app. I can export to CSV or PDF, but I want something automated that will save the data elsewhere for redundancy or additional use.
Anyway, I didn't think anything useful would come out of it. But it has. And now it's just a habit; I start a timer every time a do something without even thinking about it.

I work remotely, which really means I'm always working. There's hardly wasn't any separation between work and home until I noticed the time spent working while the family was home. Visualizing that overlap really helped me adjust things for the best.

Which, by the way, I never realized how much time is spent sleep. It's probably the thing I do the most. Aside from spending time with the family.

And leads me to what this whole time tracking this was about. Spending more of my time with the family.

I'm approaching a year of time tracking every minute of every day via @timelogger_app. It's worked out great and I've gathered some useful data from it. Mostly that I spend as much time listening to podcasts as I do sleeping.

There's a query done with each page render, so that does increase build times. But each data file is a single clients info. Think bio pages. Data files are created from API calls to a server (separate app handling that).

Whole process is able to change; nothing is set in stone.

Data File (JSON) > Template.js > Static Page

Each data file is unique and requires it's own static page.

Still, this was fun to make and it's been serving its purpose well enough for now. And @scriptableapp's need feature has definitely upped my iOS automation game.

I believe having the ability to access any directory in Files through apps like Pythonista, Scriptable, and Shortcuts with having to open these apps separately would make up for a lot of the issues I have with this.

I'm sure there are better ways to go about this, but this works for my needs. Scriptable's creator mentioned that the inability to run scripts with Bookmarks from the share sheet is an iOS limitation. Which those iOS limits are what make this whole thing a complicated feat.

A hell of a lot cleaner. Though I'm still not sure how to go back to Safari after coming back from Working Copy as you'll notice on the video.

All the code is up on my GitHub if anyone cares to use it or has suggestions for improvements.
https://t.co/AOJ1fm8z6d

However, with @scriptableapp's new addition of File Bookmarks, I can simplify this process a lot.

- Perform the same input ops as Shortcuts
- Add, format, and save the changes to the repo in the background with Bookmarks
- Commit and Push with Working Copy chained commands https://t.co/C47ePCFant

It's a little too much. Now I know there are several limitations imposed by iOS itself that prevent this from being a lot smoother. But I also believe Shortcuts should be able to access other directories in Files other than iCloud and Dropbox.

Shortcuts seem like the obvious choice. But then, I have a dizzying back and forth between apps.

- Open Shortcuts
- Get the data from the repo
- Format with Pythonista
- Go back to Working Copy to save, commit, and push
- Then back to the browser https://t.co/ondUHh7jja

Most of my media consumption, if not all, is through my phone. Therefore it makes sense to have a Shortcut that handles the archiving. I'm saving changes to a repo using @WorkingCopyApp. And I've been using @olemoritz's Pythonista to help preserve the formatting of the JSON file.

In an effort to archive the stuff I find interesting on the web, I made a repo with a JSON data file that saves the URL, Title, and Creator of any article/comic/podcast/tweet/video I want to save.

The goal is to ultimately create a database accessible through my own website.
@simonbs Ah, I see. Well, thanks for the reply man U+1f44a

@simonbs I’ve been doing some cool stuff with the File Bookmarks feature. It’s improved my whole automation setup. But I noticed you can’t run scripts that use Bookmarks from the share sheet or Siri.

Is this something that’s in the works or are you limited by the OS in some way?
There's no reason for this. I just feel like doing it.
But I think I might've found a purpose for my twitter. I'll share any obscure and random "mind-motion" here as they pop-up in my head.
My partner used to be annoying by this. Because I always start singing (poorly) the song that comes to my head out loud. But I do it so often she's now the same as me.

I just came across an interesting article on the NYT Magazine about "tiny, private mind-motions". Like most, I have plenty of those. In my case, I associate everything I heard/read/say with some old and cheesy song.
https://t.co/vxt1wm5rxM
And I keep a personal journal of sorts where I share my thoughts for the day. No one reads that. Not even myself. It's just for me; a way to offload my busy head at the end of the day.

I’ve never really known how to use Twitter. It’s almost always served as an RSS + commentary of sorts. And I rarely engage in the conversation; always a lurker.

But that doesn’t mean I don’t share my thoughts with the world. I have a blog (under redesign) where I share thoughts.
@simonbs Fantastic release man. Congrats and thank you for putting so much work into this U+1f44a With the bookmarks feature I’ll be able to build workflows I couldn’t before and it’s exciting!
